abstracts.cdata!:
Millions in rural southwestern China
            have been uplifted from the vicious cycle of poverty by an
            innovative and exhaustive poverty reduction program that,
            for the first time in China, put money directly into
            villages, financing initiatives the residents themselves suggested.

repnme.cdata!: China - Southwest Poverty Reduction Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of project outcome is
            highly satisfactory, sustainability highly likely, with high
            institutional development impacts, rendered by a highly
            satisfactory performance by the Borrower, and satisfactory
            performance by the Bank. Regardless of success, and positive
            lessons such as the strong Government support, and a good
            synergy bringing in a great variety of poverty reduction
            activities down to the township and village levels, some
            negative lessons suggest the following. False expectations,
            and funding mechanisms lead to design and implementation
            distortions, i.e., funding and repayment arrangements should
            be designed so that (a) the project beneficiaries receive
            what they themselves say they want, and, (b) the scale of
            the most cost-effective poverty reduction measures is not
            reduced or eliminated solely because it is difficult to
            determine who, or what level of government should repay.
            Although participatory project design, and preparation was
            excellent, and path breaking for its time, unfortunately,
            the focus on community empowerment, and the participatory
            approach was allowed to subside during implementation, and
            in some cases was overruled by county technical bureaus used
            to top-down planning. Furthermore, ethnic minorities
            comprise an ever greater share of China's remaining
            absolute poverty, and their needs, aspirations, and
            background are often quite distinct from majority culture,
            thus, it is essential that better mechanisms be developed to
            ensure that ethnic minorities have full access to the entire
            range of project benefits and, in particular, that ethnic
            minority villages be in charge of their own project design,
            preparation and implementation.

18867261.majtheme: Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal objectives of the
            Southwest Poverty Reduction Project are to: 1) demonstrate
            the effectiveness of a focused, multisectoral rural
            development project approach to poverty reduction; 2)
            facilitate a "market-friendly" increase in labor
            mobility from the poor areas to better-off rural and rapidly
            growing urban areas; 3) upgrade poverty monitoring at the
            national and local levels; and 4) significantly reduce
            absolute poverty in 35 of the very poorest counties in
            southwestern China. The project will comprise the following
            six components: 1) social services, including increasing the
            access and quality of primary education and enhancing the
            availability and delivery of primary and curative health
            care; 2) labor mobility, through a voluntary system of
            enhanced rural labor mobility for the upland absolute poor;
            3) rural infrastructure, including the labor-intensive
            construction of rural roads, safe drinking water supply
            systems, small-scale irrigation, agricultural drainage
            works, biogas digesters, and rural electrification; 4) land
            and farmer development, using menus of crop and livestock
            activities to increase upland agricultural productivity and
            reverse the trend of environmental degradation; 5) Township
            and Village Enterprise (TVE) development, through support
            for TVEs consisting of investment credit for
            labor-intensive, mineral, service and handicraft industries;
            and 6) institution building and poverty monitoring.

697344.trustfund:
TF029906-BNPP-POVERTY: MAINSTREAMING
            POVERTY IMPACT EVALUATION IN THE REGIONS,TF038520-CHINA: SOUTHWEST POVERTY AND
            QINBA MOUNTAINS POVERTY,TF026512-PHRD-CHINA: SOUTHWEST/QINBA
            MOUNTAINS POVERTY REDUCTION PROJECT,TF039755-CHINA - SOUTHWEST POV.REDUCTION
            & QINBA MTNS. POV. RED.,TF038460-CHINA - QINBA MOUNTAINS &
            SOUTHWEST POVERTY,TF037568-EAST ASIA REGION-N.MOUNTAINS
            AND MALUKU REG. DEV.,TF032099-ASIA;PACIFIC REGION -
            SUSTAINABLE BANKING WITH POOR,TF023092-PHRD-NATIONAL HIGHWAYS II (BANK-EXEC.),TF023091-PHRD-SOUTHWESTERN POVERTY REDUCTION

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal objectives of the
            Southwest Poverty Reduction Project are to: 1) demonstrate
            the effectiveness of a focused, multisectoral rural
            development project approach to poverty reduction; 2)
            facilitate a "market-friendly" increase in labor
            mobility from the poor areas to better-off rural and rapidly
            growing urban areas; 3) upgrade poverty monitoring at the
            national and local levels; and 4) significantly reduce
            absolute poverty in 35 of the very poorest counties in
            southwestern China. The project will comprise the following
            six components: 1) social services, including increasing the
            access and quality of primary education and enhancing the
            availability and delivery of primary and curative health
            care; 2) labor mobility, through a voluntary system of
            enhanced rural labor mobility for the upland absolute poor;
            3) rural infrastructure, including the labor-intensive
            construction of rural roads, safe drinking water supply
            systems, small-scale irrigation, agricultural drainage
            works, biogas digesters, and rural electrification; 4) land
            and farmer development, using menus of crop and livestock
            activities to increase upland agricultural productivity and
            reverse the trend of environmental degradation; 5) Township
            and Village Enterprise (TVE) development, through support
            for TVEs consisting of investment credit for
            labor-intensive, mineral, service and handicraft industries;
            and 6) institution building and poverty monitoring.
